SENT.plain: OBJECTIVES: Low participation rates in the selection of population controls are an increasing concern for the validity of case-control studies worldwide
METHODS: We conducted a pilot study to assess two approaches to recruiting population controls in a study of colorectal cancer, including a face-to-face interview and blood sample collection
In the first approach, persons identified through a population roster were invited to participate through a telephone call by an interviewer telephoning on behalf of our research center
In the second approach, individuals were identified from the lists of selected family practitioners and were telephoned on behalf of the family practitioner
RESULTS: When the second method was used, participation rates increased from 42% to 57% and the percentage of refusals decreased from 47% to 13%
The reasons for refusing to participate did not differ significantly between the two methods
CONCLUSIONS: Contact through the family practitioner yielded higher response rates in population controls in the study area
